q5.value: We thank Adam Berinsky, Andrea Campbell, and Teppei Yamamoto for helpful comments on an early draft of this design.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: We have some preliminary results (based on administrative data) that suggest that people whose wages go up due to minimum-wage increases may also become more likely to vote. There are several possible mechanisms for this: for one, more income could make it feasible for people to vote by removing barriers like housing instability and financial stress. But there could also be “interpretive effects” of such a policy change, where getting a raise because of government policy changes people’s attitudes about the role of government in their lives. We want to use a survey to explore these possible mechanisms, while taking advantage of a planned minimum wage increase in Massachusetts. On January 1, 2019, the Massachusetts minimum wage will increase from $11/hour to $12/hour for most workers. We plan to use a multi-wave survey (as well as an embedded experiment) to test how this minimum wage increase shapes people's economic well-being as well as their political efficacy. We ran the first (baseline) wave of the survey in late December, and will launch the second wave in early January to collect follow-up measures.

q16.value: We will test the hypotheses that Massachusetts’ 2019 minimum wage increase: 1) improves the economic situation of minimum-wage workers 2) increases political efficacy among minimum-wage workers Note that we do not have a mediation setup here: we are simply attempting to measure two different pathways by which minimum wage increases could drive turnout and whether there is evidence that each of them is occurring, not trying to distinguish which matters more for turnout. See the attached pre-analysis plan for more detail on our expectations. There is also a small experimental manipulation embedded in the second wave of the survey: some people will be randomly assigned to see a question that reminds them of the minimum wage increase early in the survey, while others will see it at the end. We will use this treatment to test a secondary hypothesis about how salient the minimum wage increase is for affected workers. We anticipate that: 3) being primed with a question about the minimum wage increase will not change people’s answers to the questions that make up our main outcome measures, since we anticipate the wage increase will already be relatively salient for minimum wage workers. But the PAP discusses what we will do if the primed group seems to behave differently from the unprimed group (basically, we will check whether our main diff-in-diff results depend on the primed group, and if so, we will suspect that minimum wage increases will have a major political impact only if people are reminded of them right before elections, perhaps by politicians’ statements).

q17.value: We detail four main hypothesis tests in the attached pre-analysis plan. Briefly, we have two main outcome measures, each an index measure constructed from several survey questions: we label these our “political efficacy” and “economic pessimism” measures, and their construction is described in the PAP. For each of these two outcomes, we run two different tests, each of them a difference-in-differences setup. For political efficacy, for example, we want to compare the over-time changes (before-after minimum wage increase) in political efficacy among people who are and are not affected by the minimum wage increase. We set up this simple difference-in-differences design (in regression terms, predicting the outcome measure with a dummy for whether the person is part of the group affected by the wage increase, a dummy for whether it is after the wage increase takes place, and the interaction between the two) using two different comparison groups. First, we compare our affected group (people in Massachusetts who earn between $11 and $12/hour before the minimum wage increase) to other people in the same state who are not affected by the minimum wage increase, because they already earned more than the new minimum wage (people in Massachusetts who earn between $12 and $15/hour). But because we worry that this comparison could understate the effect of the policy on minimum-wage workers’ attitudes if above-minimum-wage workers also notice and draw political conclusions from the wage increase, we then do a second test with a different comparison group. This time, we set up the same diff-in-diff, comparing affected workers in MA to low-wage workers in neighboring Connecticut, which did not increase its minimum wage in 2019. We then run the same two diff-in-diff analyses (comparing across earnings and across geography) for our other outcome measure, economic pessimism. These four tests constitute our main analyses, testing our two main hypotheses. As noted above, there is also a small experimental manipulation embedded in the second wave of the survey. We will check whether the location of the priming question within the survey changed respondents’ answers by calculating the difference in means between people who saw the question early in the survey and those who saw it at the end of the survey (focusing on people affected by the minimum wage increase, so people in Massachusetts making under $12/hour at baseline). If the priming question affects people’s responses to our main outcome measures, then we will conduct additional analyses (described in detail in the PAP) to see whether our diff-in-diff results seem to depend on the responses of people who received the priming question early in the survey.

attributes.title: Personalization and Trust in the Police: an Experiment

q1.value: Personalization and Trust in the Police: an Experiment

q2.value: Jennifer McCoy | Alban Lauka | Zachary Goldberg

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: Recent events and social and political developments have highlighted tension and mistrust towards the police in various communities in the US. Such realities can be dangerous for legitimacy, rule of law, and the overall health of the American democracy. As previous literature has linked mistrust to dehumanization, we set to explore ways to increase trust towards the police through the opposite process. Our goal is to determine whether personal information about police officers might work as humanizing elements, which could affect individual attitudes towards a police officer, or the police force in general.

q16.value: 1. Name identification increases trust in the police. 2. In-group name identification results in a sharp increase in trust in the police. 3. Out-group name identification results in a mild increase in trust in the police.

q17.value: Each respondent will provide basic personal information, and then be presented with a vignette about an encounter they could have with one police officer. The vignette presented to respondents randomly assigned to the control group will feature a police officer that does not disclose his/her name during the encounter. The vignette presented to respondents randomly assigned to the first treatment group will feature a police officer with a typically American name. The vignette presented to respondents randomly assigned to the second treatment group will feature a police officer with a typically foreign (non-American) name. Then all groups will be asked about how trustful they would feel towards that particular police officer, and then any police officer in a similar situation.

registration_responses.q1: Personalization and Trust in the Police: an Experiment
registration_responses.q2: Jennifer McCoy | Alban Lauka | Zachary Goldberg
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

Our goal is to determine whether personal information about police officers might work as humanizing elements, which could affect individual attitudes towards a police officer, or the police force in general.

The vignette presented to respondents randomly assigned to the control group will feature a police officer that does not disclose his/her name during the encounter. The vignette presented to respondents randomly assigned to the first treatment group will feature a police officer with a typically American name. The vignette presented to respondents randomly assigned to the second treatment group will feature a police officer with a typically foreign (non-American) name. Then all groups will be asked about how trustful they would feel towards that particular police officer, and then any police officer in a similar situation.

attributes.title: Text messages for GOTV in Portland (OR) 2017 General Election

q1.value: Text messages for GOTV in Portland (OR) 2017 General Election

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: This field experiment tests whether text messages can increase the return of ballots in postal ballot delivery elections. Voter turnout under election systems like Oregon’s is a behavior distinct from the behavior under traditional in-person voting, early in-person voting, and even returning voluntary no-excuse absentee ballot systems. The experiment involves a series of texts beginning with information about a ballot measure on funding Portland Community College and ending with information about where to return ballots. The experiment tests two treatments seeking to leverage distinct mechanisms for increasing return of ballots: 1) a reminder mechanism (“Calendar treatment”) and 2) increasing the social value of voting (“Adopt-a-voter treatment”). Both mechanisms have been successful in traditional voter mobilization settings, but not (to my knowledge) compared in an RCT. Unique phone households are randomly assigned to one of the two treatments. Each mechanism is implemented by a text message in the middle of the series. The Calendar treatment provides a link that will create a digital calendar reminder to return the ballot on the subject’s smart phone. The Calendar treatment is similar to “pledge-to-vote” treatments used in GOTV phone calls and canvassing, but leverages the interaction with subjects via smartphones. The Adopt-a-voter treatment asks the subject to encourage a friend or family member to return their ballot. The Adopt-a-voter treatment is similar to “friends-and-family” GOTV tactics but tailored to the postal ballot delivery voting system.

q16.value: - H1: A series of text messages will increase voter turnout in postal ballot delivery elections. o H0: No increase in turnout o Assessed using the average effect of both treatments o One tailed hypothesis - H1C1: A series of text messages will shift the temporal pattern of ballot returns in postal ballot delivery elections. o H0: No shift in temporal pattern o Assessed using the average effect of both treatments o Two tailed hypothesis because either earlier or later shift seems theoretically possible based on treatment content, but I expect the returns to be shifted earlier in response to treatments. - H1C2: A series of text messages will change rate of ballot returns at drop-boxes. o H0: No change in returns at drop-boxes o Assessed using the average effect of both treatments o Two tailed hypothesis because of possible substitution between methods of returning ballots within overall increase in returns [H1]. - H1C3: A series of text messages will change rate of ballot returns via mail. o H0: No change in returns via mail o Assessed using the average effect of both treatments o Two tailed hypothesis because of possible substitution between methods of returning ballots within overall increase in returns [H1]. - H2: The text message series including the Adopt-a-voter message will increase voter turnout in postal ballot delivery elections. o H0: No increase in turnout o Assessed using the average effect of both treatments o One tailed hypothesis - H2C1: The text message series including the Adopt-a-voter message will shift the temporal pattern of ballot returns in postal ballot delivery elections. o H0: No shift in temporal pattern o Assessed using the average effect of both treatments o Two tailed hypothesis because either earlier or later shift seems theoretically possible, but I expect the returns to be shifted earlier in response to treatments. Stronger expectation of earlier for Adopt-a-voter treatment than Calendar treatment. - H2C2: The text message series including the Adopt-a-voter message will change rate of ballot returns at drop-boxes. o H0: No change in returns at drop-boxes o Assessed using the average effect of both treatments o Two tailed hypothesis because of possible substitution between methods of returning ballots within overall increase in returns [H2]. - H2C3: The text message series including the Adopt-a-voter message will change rate of ballot returns via mail. o H0: No change in returns via mail o Assessed using the average effect of both treatments o Two tailed hypothesis because of possible substitution between methods of returning ballots within overall increase in returns [H2]. - H3: The text message series including the Calendar message will increase voter turnout. o H0: No increase in turnout o Assessed using the average effect of both treatments o One tailed hypothesis - H3C1: The text message series including the Calendar message will shift the temporal pattern of ballot returns. o H0: No shift in temporal pattern o Assessed using the average effect of both treatments o Two tailed hypothesis because either earlier or later shift seems theoretically possible based on treatment content. Expectations are divided because text may produce early shift or calendar reminder may produce late shift. - H3C2: The text message series including the Calendar message will change rate of ballot returns at drop-boxes. o H0: No change in returns at drop-boxes o Assessed using the average effect of both treatments o Two tailed hypothesis because of possible substitution between methods of returning ballots within overall increase in returns [H3]. - H3C3: The text message series including the Calendar message will change rate of ballot returns via mail. o H0: No change in returns via mail o Assessed using the average effect of both treatments o Two tailed hypothesis because of possible substitution between methods of returning ballots within overall increase in returns [H3]. - H4: The average treatment effect of the Adopt-a-voter treatment will be different from the Calendar treatment on overall turnout. o H0: No difference in turnout o Two tailed hypothesis, since I have no clear expectation about which will have a larger effect - H4C1: The average treatment effect of the Adopt-a-voter treatment will be different from the Calendar treatment shift in the temporal pattern of ballot returns. o H0: No shift in temporal pattern o Two tailed hypothesis because either earlier or later shift seems theoretically possible. However, I expect the Calendar treatment to prompt a surge in returns following the automatic Calendar reminder. - H4C2: The average treatment effect of the Adopt-a-voter treatment will be different from the Calendar treatment on rate of ballot returns at drop-boxes. o H0: No change in returns at drop-boxes o Two tailed hypothesis - H4C3: The average treatment effect of the Adopt-a-voter treatment will be different from the Calendar treatment on rate of ballot returns via mail. o H0: No change in returns via mail o Two tailed hypothesis - H5: The treatment effect will spillover to co-residents at the same address. o H0: No spillover of treatment effects o Applied to each treatment individually and pooled treatment average o Applied to each outcome: overall turnout, temporal pattern of returns, and ballot return method o One-tailed hypothesis, because backlash against spillover/dispersion seems theoretically implausible - H6: A larger proportion of the Adopt-a-voter treatment’s effect will be dispersed to co-residents at the same address than the Calendar treatment. o H0: No dispersion of treatment effects o The Adopt-a-voter treatment explicitly encourages treatment dispersion, while the Calendar treatment relies on spillover (no dispersion explicitly encouraged). o Applied to each outcome: overall turnout, temporal pattern of returns, and ballot return method o One-tailed hypothesis, because backlash against dispersion seems theoretically implausible - H7: (Heterogeneity across observational covariate – blocked randomization) Treatment effects will be different among young voters (under age 45). o H0: No change in treatment effects o Applied to each treatment individually and pooled treatment average o Applied to each outcome: overall turnout, temporal pattern of returns, and ballot return method o Two-tailed hypothesis, but increase expected based on proposition that higher education funding is more salient to young voters - H8: (Heterogeneity across observational covariate – blocked randomization) Treatment effects will be different among voters who cast ballots in the May 2017 municipal election. o H0: No change in treatment effects o Applied to each treatment individually and pooled treatment average o Applied to each outcome: overall turnout, temporal pattern of returns, and ballot return method o Two-tailed hypothesis • It may be easier to mobilize those who participated in recent local election because of habituation to voting • It may be more difficult to increase turnout among those who participated in recent local election because of fatigue and/or turnout in low profile elections is influenced by salience of specific contests on ballot - H9: (Heterogeneity across observational covariate – blocked randomization) Treatment effects will be different among voters who reside in Portland K-12 school district. o H0: No change in treatment effects o Applied to each treatment individually and pooled treatment average o Applied to each outcome: overall turnout, temporal pattern of returns, and ballot return method o Two-tailed hypothesis • It may be easier to mobilize those who reside in overlapping K-12 school district because of shared issue salience (May ballot had very large Portland K-12 school funding measure similar to PCC measure) • It may be more difficult to increase turnout among those who reside in overlapping K-12 school district because of issue fatigue (see note above about May ballot) - H10: (Heterogeneity across observational covariate – blocked randomization) Treatment effects will be larger among voters who have stronger ties to Portland area (operationalized by Portland area code for mobile phon

q17.value: - Hypothesis testing will be done using randomization inference procedure o Re-randomization procedure in original randomization undermines the assumptions used in classical hypothesis testing, so randomization inference is necessary o Randomization inference will use the same re-randomization process for each iteration as was used in original random assignment - Regression for estimating effects within randomization inference o Regression of post treatment measures on dummies for treatment conditions, with control group omitted as the reference point o OLS to examine differences in the data • Not logit/probit because this compares “typical case” rather than means within each group. o Heterogeneous treatment effects assessed with interaction terms between treatment dummies and each covariate where heterogeneity is expected (see Hypotheses) - Multi-voter households o Each analysis will be conducted among all households and among households with only a single target o Multi-target households may produce “noisy” results because: • Multi-target households may be an indication of poor data quality, especially out-of-date information • Multi-target households distort treatment effect due to violation of SUTVA assumption within households - Covariates o All outcomes will be reported using regressions with and without covariates • Main text will report estimates without covariates based on evidence of balanced assignment (i.e. re-randomization procedure) and large N of experiment o Covariates are the same as those used in the re-randomization procedure to check balance and for blocked randomization. o All covariates are from voter registration records provided by partner campaign organization. o Balance variables: • Age • Year of voter registration • Female • Registered Democrat (dummy variable, all other parties = 0) • Person of color (dummy variable = 1 where modeled race/ethnicity from partner campaign organization is non-white) • Voted in the 2012 general election • Voted in the 2013 general election • Voted in the 2014 general election • Voted in the 2015 general election • District in state House of Representatives o Block variables: • Multi-target household (dummy variable = 1 if more than one target) • Voted in May 2017 Municipal election • Resides within boundary of Portland K-12 public school district • Mobile phone has 503 or 971 area code (geographically assigned within Portland metropolitan area) • Young (under 45 years old)

q27.value: Stone's Phones and PCC Forward Campaign

Regression for estimating effects within randomization inference o Regression of post treatment measures on dummies for treatment conditions, with control group omitted as the reference point o OLS to examine differences in the data • Not logit/probit because this compares “typical case” rather than means within each group. o Heterogeneous treatment effects assessed with interaction terms between treatment dummies and each covariate where heterogeneity is expected (see Hypotheses) - Multi-voter households o Each analysis will be conducted among all households and among households with only a single target o Multi-target households may produce “noisy” results because: • Multi-target households may be an indication of poor data quality, especially out-of-date information • Multi-target households distort treatment effect due to violation of SUTVA assumption within households - Covariates o All outcomes will be reported using regressions with and without covariates • Main text will report estimates without covariates based on evidence of balanced assignment (i.e. re-randomization procedure) and large N of experiment o Covariates are the same as those used in the re-randomization procedure to check balance and for blocked randomization. o All covariates are from voter registration records provided by partner campaign organization. o Balance variables: • Age • Year of voter registration • Female • Registered Democrat (dummy variable, all other parties = 0) • Person of color (dummy variable = 1 where modeled race/ethnicity from partner campaign organization is non-white) • Voted in the 2012 general election • Voted in the 2013 general election • Voted in the 2014 general election • Voted in the 2015 general election • District in state House of Representatives o Block variables: • Multi-target household (dummy variable = 1 if more than one target) • Voted in May 2017 Municipal election • Resides within boundary of Portland K-12 public school district • Mobile phone has 503 or 971 area code (geographically assigned within Portland metropolitan area) • Young (under 45 years old)
registration_responses.q27: Stone's Phones and PCC Forward Campaign

attributes.title: The Effects of Deliberation on Argument Repertoires and Second-Order Beliefs

q1.value: The Effects of Deliberation on Argument Repertoires and Second-Order Beliefs

q5.value: The authors would like to thank Michael Neblo and William Minozzi for their continued guidance in designing this project, and would like to thank Laura Moses and Jack Brown for their work in moderating our online discussions.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: Deliberative democratic theorists have long held that the exchange of mutually acceptable reasons between peers can foster a wide range of democratic goods, from increased knowledge and efficacy to interpersonal trust to updated second-order beliefs (what we think others think). However, the empirical measurement of a few of these hypothesized effects of deliberation have thus far been carried out using surveys about deliberation, rather than deliberation itself. In this design, we used surveys conducted before and immediately after peer-to-peer deliberation about climate policy to measure participants' second-order beliefs and argument repertoires. We intend to measure whether, as deliberative democrats contend, participants learn new justifications for and against their positions, and/or update their beliefs about what those who disagree with them think, as a result of deliberating with their peers.

q16.value: We intent to measure pre/post differences in the size of argument repertoires for and against participants' positions, as well as changes in second-order beliefs about climate policy (what respondents think those who disagree with them think about different aspects of the issue). We hypothesize that deliberation should lead to increased argument repertoire size and more moderate second-order beliefs, but also that these differences will be moderated by the ideological heterogeneity of the group in which a participant is deliberating. Participants who deliberate in ideologically heterogeneous groups are expected to see larger increases in against-repertoire size and a greater decrease in the extremity of second-order beliefs, while participants who deliberate in a group with more co-ideologues are expected to see larger increases in for-repertoire size and less of a decrease in second-order beliefs.

q17.value: Participants took a pre-survey that asked them to list their initial preferences, argument repertoires, and second-order beliefs on a set of climate policy options. They then deliberated with a small group of their peers on the options included in the pre-survey for one hour, and immediately following the deliberation they completed a post-survey that asked the same preference/repertoire/second-order batteries of questions.

attributes.title: Elite Cues and Endorsement Experiments in Conflict Contexts

q1.value: Elite Cues and Endorsement Experiments in Conflict Contexts

q2.value: Natalia Garbiras Diaz | Aila Matanock | Miguel Garcia-Sanchez

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: Settlements, like many foreign policy deals, involve concessions; so, how do voters form opinions about them? In this project, we seek to answer the question of how citizens form their attitudes towards provisions included in a particular set of important agreements: peace agreements. Specifically, we argue that in low information and highly polarized contexts, acquiring information is costly and, thus, citizens will rely on elite cues to form their opinions about complex provisions included in peace agreements. In particular, even if citizens are generally be supportive of peace processes overall, their support for specific provisions may be contingent on elites' endorsements. We argue that facing complex provisions as part of peace processes, less informed individuals will likely take elite cues as information shortcuts to base their attitudes and public support for these specific provisions. We assess our theory in the context of Colombia's peace process, where we use an endorsement experiment in a survey to test for the effects of elite cues on voters' attitudes toward certain proposals included in the peace agreement signed between the government and the FARC in 2016. Understanding the effect of elite endorsements, in conflict settings, has several theoretical implications. First, this project will provide novel evidence on the sources of citizen attitude formation in contexts of violence, and, specifically, what effects elite cues have on support for rehabilitation and other crucial components of peace-building. As such, it contributes to the literature on public opinion that has long studied how citizens form their attitudes, but given several factors that may change that process. Second, as more countries with elections negotiate settlements to civil conflict, citizens' involvement in peace processes increases, either by directly by voting in a referendum or by voting on those who negotiated it, or by indirectly resisting or supporting rehabilitation of ex-combatants and other policies. Understanding what shapes citizens attitudes toward peace agreements becomes highly relevant and may point to places where inclusion is more or less beneficial for the prospects of peace.

q16.value: Main outcomes of interest: 1. General support for two of the proposals included in the peace agreement 2. Assessment of the extent to which the proposal will benefit average citizens 3. Assessment of the extent to which the proposal will benefit members of FARC 4. Assessment of the extent to which the proposal will benefit the government Hypotheses about main effects: - A proposal's endorsement by elites with high-affinity to an individual should signal a positive ratio of the benefits to costs associated with the proposal, producing an increase in the individual's support to the endorsed proposal. Conversely, endorsements by elites with low-affinity to voters should convey negative information about such tally, decreasing voters' support to the endorsed proposal. These effects should only exist when endorsements come from controversial elites, defined as elites who take a clear and polarizing stance on the peace absent any endorsement, even if respondents report closer personal affinities to those uncontroversial actors. - Individuals with more information about a proposal should be less likely to use elite endorsements to form their opinions than individuals who lack such information. Heterogeneous effects: - Political knowledge: The effect of elite cues conditioned by political knowledge should follow a U-shaped relationship, where citizens with levels of political knowledge that locate them in the center of the distribution should be the least susceptible to elite cues. - Specific knowledge about the peace agreement: Individuals better informed about the provisions included in the peace agreement should be less influenced by elite endorsements. - Victimizaction: The effect of elite endorsements should be smaller among victims of conflict.

q17.value: Each survey respondent will receive two proposals. For each proposal we first randomize whether the individual receives more information about it or not; and then, we randomly assign one of the following types of endorsers: i) pure control; ii) neutral; or iii) controversial (defined as one polarizing elite). In this context, we define a controversial endorser as either the current president Juan Manuel Santos or ex-president Alvaro Uribe-Velez (one of the clearest opponents of peace agreement). We also block based on strata defined by the respondents' level of affinity to president Santos and ex-president Uribe. (1) For the main effects of elite endorsements, we will estimate the effects by running an OLS regression with robust standard errors of the main outcomes of interest regressed on a treatment indicator (pure control, neutral, controversial) interacted with the individual's level of affinity with the controversial elite. (2) We also test for the effect of elite endorsements conditional on the individuals' prior knowledge about the proposal, with a difference-in-differences estimator, leveraging the exogenous manipulation of the amount of information about the proposal provided to survey respondents. (3) We estimate the heterogeneous treatment effects described in the previous section, with the same specification described in (1) interacting these effects with each one of the hypothesized intervening variables (political knowledge, knowledge about the agreement, victimization).

q27.value: IPSOS (polling firm) supervised by the Observatorio de la Democracia (hosted by the Department of Political Science of the University of Los Andes in Bogota, Colombia)

attributes.title: Can Descriptive Representation Create Slack for Poor Performance?

q1.value: Can Descriptive Representation Create Slack for Poor Performance?

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: This study offers and tests a theory of ethnic voting that incorporates both material and non-material motivations into the voter’s decision-making calculus, and systematically characterizes how these motivations vary among different sub-populations within an ethnic group. Specifically, it argues that descriptive ethnic representation is a non-material benefit that – when provided – can create slack for the poor delivery of public goods and services by a coethnic politician. Descriptive representation is valuable because of the respect, recognition, and status it is felt to bestow upon members of the ethnic group. Some subpopulations within the ethnic group hold a higher demand for descriptive representation than others, and are therefore more likely to trade-off good governance with the symbolic provision of status and recognition. This approach to ethnic voting differs from both instrumental views and social identification views in the extant political science literature. Unlike instrumental views, it does not see ethnicity as simply a signal for performance or patronage – which would imply that ethnic voting would not exist in the presence of full information on these variables. Unlike social identification views, it does not claim that voters do not care about performance or patronage and are concerned only with affirming their ethnic identities. Unlike both, it attempts to systematically characterize variation within ethnic groups in how much each type of concern matters. It expects that certain subpopulations weigh identity concerns more than others, and may therefore be willing to accept poor performance by co-ethnic politicians on the material front.

q16.value: Main Effect (H1): The likelihood that a voter will vote to re-elect an incumbent increases if the incumbent provides descriptive representation, regardless of whether the incumbent has provided poor or good governance while in office. Heterogenous Treatment Effect (H2): The effect of descriptive representation on incumbent support will be amplified among lower social classes. Heterogenous Treatment Effect (H3): The effect of descriptive representation on incumbent support will be amplified among men. Heterogenous Treatment Effect (H4): The effect of descriptive representation on incumbent support will be amplified among those who identify more highly with their ethnicity. Heterogenous Treatment Effect (H5): The effect of descriptive representation on incumbent support will be amplified among those who have been exposed to disrespect on the basis of their ethnicity.

q17.value: Respondents will be read vignettes that provide information on a hypothetical incumbent running for re-election in their constituency. The incumbent’s features will be experimentally manipulated on two dimensions: (1) governance and (2) descriptive representation, using a 2 × 2 factorial design. Respondents will then be asked to indicate their likelihood of voting to re-elect the candidate on a scale from 1 to 5, where 1 is “not at all likely” and 5 is “extremely likely.” Results from the experiment will be used to estimate the effect of descriptive representation on the likelihood of voting for the incumbent (by pooling across good and poor governors, and by looking at the effect of descriptive representation among only good governors and only poor governors). The survey will also collect information on respondents’ gender, level of education, and level of social identification with ethnicity. Heterogenous treatment effects will be estimated by interacting the treatment indicator with the hypothesized moderating variable, and by subsetting the data.

attributes.title: Perceptions of Intermediaries in Off-Grid Solar Services [Part 2 of study]

q1.value: Perceptions of Intermediaries in Off-Grid Solar Services [Part 2 of study]

q5.value: We thank the Tata Center for Technology and Design at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology for its generous support of this project. , Data will be collected with support from the Busara Center for Behavioral Economics in Nairobi, Kenya.

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: This project uses a conjoint analysis survey to elicit heterogeneous household preferences for off-grid solar technologies and services in rural Kenya. Understanding and describing these preferences is critical to off-grid energy business models. The data from this survey will be used to understand household preferences for intermediary characteristics. Intermediaries in this study focus on representatives of organizations (or parts of organizations) that help households access solar services.

q16.value: Much of the literature on off-grid solar technologies focuses on the viability of specific technologies and their related technical configurations, costs, and capacity (Alstone et al., 2015). Different solar technologies are associated with different price points, end-uses, and barriers to adoption. While there is increasing focus on the business models associated with off-grid solar (Singh, 2016), there is little attention on the intermediary organizations that work in the middle to help link service providers to local communities. Previous studies of intermediaries identify a positive relationship between intermediaries and social services (Grantham and Baruah, 2017; Krishna, 2011; Saha et al., 2013). H1: Households will trust NGOs more than others for access to solar services. H2: Households will trust front-line workers from within their community more than an outsider. H3: Households will trust intermediaries that have connections to the local service provider. H4: Households will trust intermediaries that provide financing.

q17.value: To test these hypotheses I propose to use a conjoint analysis survey. Conjoint analysis surveys “ask respondents to choose from or rate hypothetical profiles that combine multiple attributes, enabling researchers to estimate the relative influence of each attribute value on the resulting choice or rating” (Hainmueller et al., 2014, p. 2). This approach allows for joint effect of different attributes on an overall judgment (Rao, 2014). Paired conjoint analysis has been shown to come closest to observed behavior (Hainmueller et al., 2015) . Data will be analyzed using a binomial logistic regression model (binary choice outcome) to determine the effect of different attributes on the stated choice preference of respondents. In addition to binomial logistic regression, we will also explore using the cjoint package in R (Oliveros and Schuster, 2018).

q19.value: 360 respondents, each responding to 6-8 choice sets per conjoint (n = 2160 - 2280)

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: See Wong 2015 "Citizenship, Service, and Sacrifice: Why does the public support citizenship for military service but not for firefighters?"

q16.value: (1) Do American support the granting of citizenship in exchange for military service more so than for other kinds of service (like fire fighting). (2) Do democrats and republicans differ in their attitudes toward the granting of citizenship in return for different types of service: especially, do they differ in their attitudes about whether military service is a special kind of service in regards citizenship. (This is a moderating effects hypothesis)

q17.value: Hypothesis 1 will be tested using a different of means test statistic and a large sample reference distribution (see Winston Lin 2013 and the Don Green Lab SOP for a discussion of randomization justified standard errors) Hypothesis 2 will be tested in the same framework, but looking for moderating effects of partisanship as theoretically motivated by the 2015 working paper.

q23.value: The research was done under the IRB of the Cooperative Congressional Election Study

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: The goal of this project is to develop a noble theory of alliance credibility and to better understand when and why nuclear proliferation happens within military alliances. This research conducts a survey experiment in South Korea testing public and elite's perception of alliance credibility and their interest in a nuclear weapons program, contributing vital data to my development of this theory. Recent international relations (IR) scholarship questions whether credibility matters in international security, but policymakers dealing with issues of extended nuclear deterrence believe that credibility is essential to assuring weaker allies of protection against threats and preventing them from building independent nuclear arsenals. In addition, scholars and policymakers fear that the current US president’s negative rhetoric might damage relations between the United States and its important allies, and worse yet, encourage allies to develop their own nuclear weapons program for deterrence from nuclear adversaries. Thus, my project addresses fundamental questions in international relations: does credibility matter in international politics? Furthermore, when states are under the protection of a great power’s nuclear umbrella, why do some decide to build nuclear weapons, while others do not?

q16.value: By developing a framework of alliance credibility, I argue that client states evaluate the worth of a nuclear umbrella according to perceived performance of the security provider in other crises. When the security patron performs poorly in a related crisis, the client state is more likely to doubt the willingness of the patron to come to its defense and, thus, more likely to pursue independent nuclear capabilities.

q17.value: This research employ survey experiment method and test elites and public's perception of alliance credibility and their support of South Korea's independent nuclear weapons program. I conduct survey experiment at the South Korea Diplomatic Academy as well as the public survey using South Korean survey firm.

Thus, my project addresses fundamental questions in international relations: does credibility matter in international politics? attributes.title: Rule Formalization, Gender Congruence, and Rule Following: Examining Prosocial Rule Breaking for Internal and External Stakeholders

q1.value: Rule Formalization, Gender Congruence, and Rule Following: Examining Prosocial Rule Breaking for Internal and External Stakeholders

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: While scholars have long discussed the benefits and consequences of bureaucratic rules, less attention has been paid to rule compliance. How can managers get employees to comply with organizational rules? This management question applies across sectors—for-profit, nonprofit, and government, but is especially important in the public sector. Rules are in place to limit the discretion of street-level bureaucrats to ensure all citizens are treated fairly and equally (Bozeman & Scott, 1996; Scott, 1997). In response to calls for research to examine how external stakeholders are examined by rules (Pandey, Pandey, & Van Ryzin, 2017), our study focuses on prosocial rule breaking for both an internal and external stakeholder. Formalization, the degree to which organizational policies and procedures are written (Pugh et al., 1963), is a key attribute for effective rules (DeHart-Davis, 2017). We examine whether formal, written rules are more likely to be followed than more informal, unwritten rules. Since a person inherently conveys the rule, we also examine how the gender of the manager influences rule following. This study contributes to research on street-level bureaucrats and prosocial rule bending. Theories on street level bureaucrats center on street level bureaucrats’ discretion to interpret and enact organizational rules (Lipsky, 1980; Maynard-Moody & Musheno, 2003). We focus on the citizen-agent perspective (Maynard-Moody & Musheno, 2003), where street level bureaucrats make a judgement about the citizen and use their discretion to use organizational rules as they see fit. Bureaucrats will rigidly apply the rules to citizens viewed as underserving, whereas they will bend the rules for citizens viewed as deserving. Rules may be bent or broken for both self-serving and prosocial motives. Although rules are more likely to be bent to help others rather than out of self-interest (DeHart Davis, 2017). Prosocial rule breaking: is when “an employee intentionally violates a formal organizational policy, regulation, or prohibition with the primary intention of promoting the welfare of the organization or one of its stakeholders” (Morrison, 2006, 10). O’Leary’s (2014) studies on government guerillas provide examples of this. Rule bending can be beneficial for organizations (Brockmann, 2015). Realatedly, Borry (2017) found rule bending to be more prevalent where the ethical climate emphasizes the organization’s interest. Contributing to research on representative bureaucracy, we also examine whether who gives the rules matters. Researchers have linked passive representation, the mere presence of diverse groups in the bureaucracy, to active representation, where government employees help advance the social groups they represent (Mosher, 1968). For example, Marvel (2015) found female teachers with female principals are more likely to work overtime. However, the influence of gender congruence on rule following has yet to be examined. We employ an experiment to advance our understanding of rule formalization and representative bureaucracy on rule following and breaking. Using a MTurk survey experiment, we test two scenarios. In the first, a middle manager is given a written or unwritten rule to suspend a very good employee without pay for a week for being late to work multiple times in a pay period. In the second, a frontline employee at a large foundation is asked whether they would accept a grant application from a nonprofit organization that provides after-school care for disadvantaged youth that was submitted an hour after the deadline, which would break the rule that all grants must be received by 5pm. For both scenarios, we vary the gender of the manager giving the rule, both written and unwritten. For the unwritten rules, we use audio clips of male and female computer generated voices reading the written rules. We examine how choice architecture of government rules, such as formalization, and gender congruence influence rule following. Both our scenarios place the respondent in a potential prosocial rule breaking scenario, where respondents could break the rule to help a good employee or a nonprofit organization that may be viewed as deserving. We hope to shed light on theories of formalization and representative bureaucracy as well as growing research on prosocial rule breaking for internal and external stakeholders.

q16.value: Our first hypothesis is that written rules have greater compliance. Our second hypothesis is that respondents will be more likely to comply with rules that comes from a boss of the same gender. The third hypothesis is that written rules will moderate the effect of gender on rule compliance.

q17.value: The hypotheses will be tested with appropriate bivariate and multivariate statistics for dichotomous outcomes. For the written/unwritten treatment this means a proportional difference test. As for the gender match this will require a chi-squared test as there are four categories of gender match of boss and respondents (i.e. male-male, male-female, female-male, female-female) with a dichotomous dependent variable. This second hypothesis may also be tested in terms of gender match or no gender match and the appropriate statistical test in this case is a proportional difference test. The final test is an interaction and, thus, we will need to use a multivariate statistical technique, which will likely be binary logistic regression. Two-way ANOVA could be used to test the interaction but the assumptions of ANOVA are slightly violated by our dichotomous compliance variable. However, the use of ANOVA with dichotomous variables is used in some contexts. If the two way ANOVA analysis supports the hypothesis and doesn't contradict the findings from the logistic regression then this will be the test that is reported in the final write-up. However, given the non-continuous dependent variable, we believe the use of logistic regression is the better choice.

registration_responses.q1: Rule Formalization, Gender Congruence, and Rule Following: Examining Prosocial Rule Breaking for Internal and External Stakeholders
